overview.short: Myroides species are Gram-negative, aerobic, non-fermentative rods (formerly within Flavobacterium) that can act as opportunistic pathogens and are notable for a strong characteristic odor.
overview.clinical_context: Typically recovered from environmental sources and occasionally from opportunistic infections (e.g., wound/soft tissue, urinary tract, or bloodstream), especially in immunocompromised patients.

field_notes.Oxidase: Typically oxidase positive among non-fermentative Gram-negative rods, helping separate from many Enterobacterales.
field_notes.Glucose Fermentation: Generally non-fermentative; sugar fields are usually negative.
field_notes.Pigment: Many isolates produce yellow pigmentation on non-selective media.

key_differentiators.notes: Aerobic non-fermenter profile argues against Enterobacterales.
Oxidase positivity helps separate from common oxidase-negative non-fermenters.
Proteolytic activity (gelatinase/lipase) is a useful supportive trait.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping ecology and phenotypes; both may be yellow-pigmented, oxidase-positive, non-fermenters.
Similar yellow-pigmented, oxidase-positive non-fermentative rods; requires higher-resolution ID.
Can overlap in non-fermenter phenotype and colony appearance.

when_to_question_identification: Strong lactose fermentation or clear A/A TSI pattern suggests Enterobacterales, not Myroides.
Oxidase negativity suggests Acinetobacter or other oxidase-negative non-fermenters.
Marked motility suggests Pseudomonas-like organisms rather than Myroides.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Best practical approach to separate Myroides from closely related yellow-pigmented non-fermenters.
Supports non-fermenter group placement and helps narrow common confusions.
Supportive trait that may help triage within non-fermentative Gram-negative rods.
